questions.text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Her last Pap smear 3 years ago showed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. Testing for human papillomavirus was negative at that time. On questioning, she has had fatigue and an increase in abdominal girth despite a 5-kg (11.0-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease and Hashimoto thyroiditis. Menarche was at the age of 10 years and her last menstrual period was 2 years ago. She does not have any children. Current medications include omeprazole and levothyroxine. Abdominal examination shows shifting dullness. There is tenderness to palpation of the right lower quadrant but no guarding or rebound. Bimanual palpation shows a small uterus and a right adnexal mass. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Chocolate cyst of the right ovary

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excessive proliferation of the endometrial glands can be seen in endometrial cancer, which typically affects postmenopausal women with a history of prolonged estrogen exposure (e.g., due to nulliparity). However, the characteristic manifestation of endometrial cancer is vaginal bleeding. In addition, endometrial cancer is usually not associated with an adnexal mass.

Hyperproliferation of the endometrium may also be seen in estrogen-producing sex cord-stromal tumors of the ovary (i.e., granulosa cell tumors or theca cell tumors). However, these tumors are very rare and other symptoms of hyperestrogenism are also expected, such as postmenopausal vaginal bleeding or breast tenderness. In addition, this patient has a small uterus on pelvic examination, making hyperplastic endometrium unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

In patients with an adnexal mass and symptoms of advanced ovarian cancer, serum CA-125 can be used as a tumor marker for malignant ovarian epithelial cell cancer. This marker should be used in conjunction with transvaginal ultrasound to assess the size and characteristics of the adnexal mass. In patients with a high probability of ovarian cancer, surgical evaluation should follow for a conclusive diagnosis. After diagnosis and initiation of treatment for ovarian cancer, CA-125 levels can be used as a prognostic marker and for the assessment of treatment response.

Serum CA-125 levels are not used for screening in asymptomatic individuals at average risk because of limited sensitivity, specificity, and positive predictive value. Elevated serum CA-125 levels can be caused by other types of cancer (e.g., endometrial cancer, fallopian tube cancer, lung cancer) and, especially in premenopausal women, by a number of benign causes (e.g., endometriosis, pregnancy).

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated β-hCG levels in a patient with typical symptoms of ovarian cancer are consistent with certain malignant ovarian germ cell tumors (e.g., dysgerminomas, nongestational choriocarcinomas), which primarily affect female individuals aged 10–30 years. Epithelial ovarian cancer, which is more likely in this postmenopausal patient, does not cause elevated serum β-hCG levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Prolonged prothrombin time is typically seen in patients with impaired production of clotting factor VII due to severe hepatic impairment (e.g., in advanced cirrhosis). Hepatic impairment in ovarian cancer may be seen in cases of advanced hepatic metastasis. However, other symptoms of hepatic injury (e.g., jaundice, palmar erythema) would be expected and metastatic dissemination usually starts with solitary liver nodes that would not cause hepatic impairment.

The finding of ascites in patients with ovarian cancer is typically a result of fluid production of tumor cells in the intraabdominal cavity with obstruction of fluid reuptake due to peritoneal metastasis. Ascites in ovarian cancer is usually not the result of reduced oncotic pressure due to impaired hepatic production of proteins (which is the mechanism of ascites in liver cirrhosis).

E) INCORRECT:

Chocolate cysts or ovarian endometriomas can form when menstrual debris builds up over time due to endometriosis. Although endometriomas may manifest with an adnexal mass similar to what is seen in this patient, they usually affect premenopausal women. Furthermore, pain is a common feature in patients with endometriosis but is absent in this patient. Instead, there are symptoms of weight loss and ascites, which, especially in the context of an adnexal mass, are more concerning for ovarian cancer.

F) INCORRECT:

Cervical dysplasia found on screening Pap smear is associated with subsequent development of cervical cancer. Early cervical cancer is usually asymptomatic, but late cervical cancer is associated with vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, or pain during intercourse, none of which this patient has. Ovarian cancer does not cause cervical dysplasia.

This patient's last Pap smear revealed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. Given the negative HPV test, her risk for high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia is very low (< 2%).
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, ascites, weight loss, and an adnexal mass, all of which are suggestive of advanced ovarian cancer. An important risk factor for this condition is an elevated number of lifetime ovulations due to nulliparity, early menarche, and late menopause.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravid woman at 15 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department because of a 6-hour history of progressive lower abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She had difficulty conceiving for 2 years and in vitro fertilization was successfully attempted 4 months ago. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows right lower quadrant tenderness with rebound and guarding. Pelvic examination shows a tender right adnexal mass and a gravid uterus consistent in size with a 15-week gestation. The fetal heart rate is 160/min. Transvaginal pelvic ultrasound with Doppler shows a 3-cm cyst in the right ovary consistent with a corpus luteum cyst and absent arterial flow to the right ovary. The patient undergoes emergency exploratory laparoscopy, which discloses a necrotic right ovary. Right oophorectomy is performed. Fetal monitoring shows a reassuring heart rate. The patient is concerned about the effects of this procedure on her pregnancy and her fetus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's pregnancy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

During the first trimester, the corpus luteum produces the progesterone needed to maintain the pregnancy, and, therefore, progesterone supplementation is essential in patients who undergo removal of the corpus luteum (via oophorectomy) before 10 weeks' gestation. From 10–12 weeks' gestation onward, the placenta produces sufficient progesterone to maintain the pregnancy and the corpus luteum regresses. Thus, during the second and third trimesters, neither unilateral nor bilateral oophorectomy will significantly decrease progesterone levels. Therefore, this patient should be reassured about the viability of her pregnancy and should receive standard surgical follow-up and routine prenatal care.

Corpus luteum cysts are common during pregnancy and usually resolve by the end of the first trimester.

B) INCORRECT:

Estrogen supplementation therapy is indicated in patients who undergo bilateral oophorectomy because this procedure results in hypoestrogenism. After unilateral oophorectomy, however, the remaining ovary is still capable of producing sufficient estrogen. Furthermore, during the second trimester of pregnancy, the placenta also starts to produce estrogen. Therefore, estrogen supplementation therapy is not indicated in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulsatile leuprolide therapy is used in the treatment of infertility as it stimulates the release of follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone. However, leuprolide is not needed to maintain pregnancy. In fact, leuprolide is contraindicated during pregnancy as it is teratogenic.

D) INCORRECT:

Progesterone supplementation therapy is indicated after oophorectomy with the removal of the corpus luteum in pregnant women at < 10–12 weeks' gestation. At 15 weeks' gestation, the placenta produces sufficient progesterone to maintain the pregnancy; therefore, this patient does not require progesterone supplementation therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's oophorectomy is not an indication for termination of pregnancy, as neither the loss of one ovary nor the procedure itself is expected to pose a risk to the pregnancy.
questions.hint: Progesterone, which is essential for the maintenance of pregnancy, is produced by different tissues over the course of pregnancy.

questions.text:
Routine pregnancy ultrasound screening in a 28-year-old gravida 3, para 2 woman confirms a viable 12-week single intrauterine gestation and reveals an adnexal mass. Imaging reveals a 4-cm anechoic mass with a single 1-mm septation. She has no personal or family history of breast or ovarian cancer. She has not had any pelvic or abdominal pain. She has had good weight gain during her pregnancy and reports no vaginal bleeding or discharge.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Reimage the area during the second trimester
Inform the patient that no further evaluation is needed

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic intervention is not required in a patient who is asymptomatic with a cyst that appears to be benign (simple, with a single septation).

B) INCORRECT:

Many tumor markers, including cancer antigen 125 (CA 125), are altered by pregnancy and are thus of limited value in pregnant women.

C) CORRECT:

The causes of adnexal masses in pregnancy include functional, corpus luteal, and paraovarian cysts; cystic teratomas; serous and mucinous cystadenomas; endometriomas; leiomyomas; and ovarian malignancies.

Most ovarian masses in pregnancy resolve spontaneously. Those that are most likely to resolve are diagnosed before 16 weeks, are less than 5 to 6 cm in diameter, and are simple in nature (anechoic; smooth, thin walls; no septations) according to ultrasound.

Given that this patient's mass has characteristics that make spontaneous resolution likely, the most appropriate next step is to reassess the mass during the second trimester. The patient will be due for second-trimester ultrasound screening between 18 and 22 weeks' gestation, and it would be reasonable to use this opportunity to reimage the mass.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for a simple ovarian cyst with a single septation that is found on pelvic ultrasound screening during pregnancy is repeat imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Planning no further evaluation or waiting until the patient delivers to obtain additional data would not be appropriate because changes could occur during that time frame. Masses that do not resolve during pregnancy are more likely to result in torsion, rupture, or obstruction of labor.

E) INCORRECT:

Planning no further evaluation or waiting until the patient delivers to obtain additional data would not be appropriate because changes could occur during that time frame. Masses that do not resolve during pregnancy are more likely to result in torsion, rupture, or obstruction of labor.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman presents with four weeks of abdominal bloating and mild pelvic discomfort to the clinic. She has been postmenopausal for 12 years and denies any vaginal bleeding. She reports no significant past medical history. Pelvic examination detects a complex left adnexal mass measuring 7 cm on transvaginal ultrasound, with both cystic and solid components. A basic metabolic panel and complete blood count are within normal limits (see report).
Transvaginal ultrasound: Complex left adnexal mass measuring 7 cm with both cystic and solid components
Which of the following serum markers is most appropriate to measure next in this patient’s workup?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-hCG) is used to evaluate pregnancy status and diagnose gestational trophoblastic disease or germ cell tumors. In a 67-year-old postmenopausal woman, pregnancy is unlikely, and germ cell tumors are rare, making beta-hCG measurement unnecessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a marker for germ cell tumors, such as yolk sac tumors, more common in younger patients. In a 67-year-old woman with a complex adnexal mass, epithelial ovarian neoplasms are more likely, making CA-125 a more relevant marker.

C) CORRECT:

Serum CA-125 is a glycoprotein often elevated in epithelial ovarian cancers, particularly serous carcinoma, the most common subtype. In postmenopausal women with a complex adnexal mass, the suspicion for malignancy increases, making CA-125 a valuable marker for risk stratification. Although not used for screening due to limited specificity, CA-125 aids in diagnosis and monitoring disease progression or treatment response in established cases.

Key learning point: CA 125 is an essential tumor marker in the workup of a complex ovarian mass in postmenopausal women, as it is commonly elevated in epithelial ovarian cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is a marker for germ cell tumors like dysgerminomas, common in younger women. In a 67-year-old woman with a complex adnexal mass, epithelial malignancy is more likely, reducing the utility of LDH measurement.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman from a long-term care facility is brought to the clinic by her daughter due to progressive abdominal distension and early satiety for two months. She is 20 years postmenopausal and has not received hormone therapy. She has no significant family history. Physical examination reveals a firm, irregular left adnexal mass (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values


CA-125
1200 U/mL
< 35 U/mL


Transvaginal ultrasound: Predominantly solid 7-cm adnexal mass
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic biopsy in suspected ovarian malignancy risks tumor rupture and peritoneal dissemination, complicating staging and treatment. Surgical resection through an open approach allows for comprehensive staging and debulking, minimizing intraoperative tumor spillage.

B) CORRECT:

The presentation of a postmenopausal woman with a firm, irregular adnexal mass, elevated CA-125 levels, and a predominantly solid mass on ultrasound suggests ovarian malignancy. Management of suspected ovarian cancer involves surgical staging and optimal debulking, best performed by a gynecologic oncologist. Their expertise ensures accurate intraoperative assessment and tailored adjuvant treatment decisions based on precise staging and cytoreduction.

Key learning point: In postmenopausal women, a solid adnexal mass with elevated CA-125 is highly suspicious for ovarian cancer, and referral to a gynecologic oncologist is recommended for further evaluation and management.

C) INCORRECT:

Chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel requires a definitive histopathologic diagnosis and established disease stage. Without tissue confirmation, initiating chemotherapy is premature. Surgical intervention is needed for diagnosis, staging, and potential cytoreduction.

D) INCORRECT:

Pelvic MRI is useful for characterizing indeterminate adnexal masses. However, in this case, the combination of a solid adnexal mass, elevated CA-125, and postmenopausal status strongly suggests malignancy. Further imaging is unnecessary, as the focus should be on surgical evaluation and management.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of severe right lower quadrant pain that began 6 hours ago while exercising. She reports nausea and has vomited twice. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Vital signs are BP, 108/72; P, 105; T, 37.1°C (98.8°F). Physical examination shows right lower quadrant tenderness with guarding and a tender, mobile right adnexal mass on pelvic examination. Pregnancy test is negative. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic study?

choices.text: CT abdomen and pelvis with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI pelvis is indicated if ultrasound findings are inconclusive or for further characterization of complex masses.

B) INCORRECT:

CT abdomen and pelvis is not the first-line imaging modality for evaluating adnexal masses.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Transvaginal ultrasound is the first-line imaging modality for all patients with adnexal masses. In this acute presentation with severe pain and physical examination findings concerning for ovarian torsion or other urgent conditions, immediate transvaginal ultrasound is essential to evaluate the adnexal mass and guide urgent management decisions.

D) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic laparoscopy is an invasive procedure reserved for cases in which the diagnosis remains unclear after complete evaluation, including imaging. Noninvasive imaging should be performed first.

E) INCORRECT:

Transabdominal ultrasound is not as sensitive as transvaginal ultrasound and serves as an adjunct or alternative when transvaginal ultrasound is not possible.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old postmenopausal woman, G3P3, presents with two months of persistent bloating, lower abdominal pressure, early satiety, and a 3 kg weight loss. She has no medical comorbidities and is not on hormone replacement therapy. On pelvic examination, a firm, irregular, left adnexal mass is palpated (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
3 ng/mL
< 5 ng/mL


Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG)
2 mIU/mL
< 5 mIU/mL


Cancer antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9)
20 U/mL
< 37 U/mL



Transvaginal ultrasound: 5 cm complex adnexal mass with internal septations
Which of the following laboratory values is most valuable in further evaluating the suspected malignant nature of this adnexal mass?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a marker for germ cell tumors, such as yolk sac tumors, typically seen in younger patients. This 62-year-old postmenopausal woman with a complex adnexal mass is more likely to have an epithelial ovarian neoplasm, which rarely elevates AFP.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum inhibin is associated with ovarian sex cord-stromal tumors, like granulosa cell tumors, which often present with hormone-related symptoms. This patient’s systemic symptoms and complex adnexal mass suggest an epithelial process, making inhibin measurement less informative.

C) CORRECT:

CA-125 is a glycoprotein marker elevated in epithelial ovarian cancers, which are common in postmenopausal women. In this patient, the complex adnexal mass with internal septations on ultrasound suggests a potential malignancy. While CA-125 is not entirely specific, its predictive value is higher in postmenopausal women, where benign causes of elevation are less common. Measuring CA-125 levels aids in assessing the likelihood of malignancy and guides further evaluation and management.

Key learning point: In postmenopausal women with an adnexal mass, CA-125 is the most essential tumor marker for the work-up of suspected epithelial ovarian cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is linked to rapidly proliferating tumors, such as dysgerminomas, affecting younger women. This postmenopausal woman’s presentation and complex adnexal mass suggest an epithelial process, not a germ cell tumor, making LDH less relevant.
